His family spent weeks trying to locate him after receiving conflicting information from officials. Ultimately, the Department of Homeland Security confirmed his deportation to the wrong country. Advocacy groups, including Cristosal and the League of United Latin American Citizens (LULAC), were unable to obtain clear answers during the search.

title: U.S. Citizen's Family Deported to Mexico After Missed Immigration Hearing
summary: Christina Salazar and her four children — three of whom are U.S. citizens — were deported to Mexico in December 2024 after Salazar missed an immigration hearing. Salazar had recently given birth to premature twins and was advised by doctors to recover at home during the scheduled court date. Despite the medical circumstances, the family was detained and deported without access to basic necessities like coats in cold weather. Her husband, Federico Arellano, a U.S. citizen, has fought to reunite with his family after the deportation to Reynosa, Mexico, where they had no contacts or resources.

title: Nearly 40 Student Visas Revoked Over Minor Infractions Amid Crackdown
summary: In early April 2025, U.S. immigration authorities revoked the visas of nearly 40 international students across major universities, often citing minor or dismissed legal infractions such as traffic violations. The revocations followed comments by Secretary of State Marco Rubio boasting about intensified scrutiny of foreign students. Universities affected include UC Berkeley, UCLA, Stanford, and Ohio State. Immigration attorneys and advocacy groups raised alarms about due process violations, as many students were not given prior notice or clear explanations before their visas were revoked.

title: U.S. Citizen with Intellectual Disabilities Wrongfully Detained by Border Patrol
summary: On April 8, 2025, 19-year-old U.S. citizen Jose Hermosillo was arrested by Customs and Border Protection agents in Tucson, Arizona, and briefly prosecuted for illegal entry. Despite providing documentation of his citizenship, Hermosillo — who suffers from intellectual disabilities, cannot read or write, and has difficulty speaking — was detained for 10 days. Officials justified the arrest based on a sworn statement Hermosillo signed under questioning, although family members and advocates argue he could not have understood the form. The incident drew national attention to the treatment of disabled individuals in immigration enforcement.

title: Two U.S. Citizen Children, Ages 4 and 7, Deported to Honduras
summary: On April 25, 2025, two U.S. citizen children, ages 4 and 7, were deported to Honduras alongside their undocumented mother, following detention at a routine ICE check-in in Louisiana. According to their lawyer, the mother was given no meaningful choice to leave her children in the United States. The 4-year-old boy suffers from late-stage cancer and was deprived of critical medications and access to doctors while in ICE custody. The deportation raised alarms about due process violations and the Trump administration’s handling of U.S. citizen minors caught up in mass immigration enforcement sweeps.

title: Two-Year-Old U.S. Citizen Detained and Scheduled for Deportation
summary: In late April 2025, a two-year-old U.S. citizen, identified in court records as V.M.L., was detained with her mother and 11-year-old sibling during a routine immigration check-in at the New Orleans ICE office. Despite documentation showing her birth in New Orleans in 2023, the child was processed for deportation. Lawyers argued that the deportation occurred without adequate opportunity for the child's father, a U.S. citizen, to assert custody rights. A federal judge expressed serious concerns about the violation of the child's due process rights, and immigration advocates raised alarms about broader citizenship rights violations.

title: German Teenagers Strip-Searched and Deported for Incomplete Travel Plans
summary: In March 2025, two German teenagers, Charlotte Pohl (19) and Maria Lepere (18), were detained by U.S. Customs and Border Protection after arriving in Honolulu, Hawaii, without proof of accommodations for their entire stay. The young women reported being interrogated for hours, strip-searched, placed in prison uniforms, and held in cells with criminal detainees before being deported. Immigration authorities cited visa violations for the deportation, but civil liberties advocates condemned the treatment as unnecessarily harsh for travelers with no criminal background.

title: Members of Congress Condemn Conditions at Louisiana Detention Facilities
summary: In April 2025, members of Louisiana's congressional delegation publicly condemned the conditions at state detention facilities where immigrants, including international students like Rümeysa Öztürk, were being held. After visiting the facilities and meeting with detainees, lawmakers described inhumane conditions, lack of due process, and raised concerns about the treatment of legally present students. The events highlighted broader criticisms of the Trump administration's immigration and detention policies targeting international students.

title: Rookie Teacher Deported Shortly After Beginning Career in Florida
summary: Wualner Sauceda, a 24-year-old science teacher at Palm Springs Middle School in Hialeah, Florida, was detained in early January 2025 and deported to Honduras on February 6. Sauceda had no known criminal history and had just begun his teaching career when he was arrested. His deportation sparked outrage among students, parents, and immigration advocates who questioned the administration's sweeping enforcement actions against community members with strong ties to the United States.

title: Maryland Resident Alexi Canas Detained Over Minor Traffic Violation
summary: On March 10, 2025, Alexi Canas, a Maryland resident with no criminal record, was detained after appearing in court to address a suspended license charge. Canas was flagged through the Frederick County Sheriff's Office 287(g) program, which allows local law enforcement to collaborate with ICE. His detention raised alarms about the targeting of individuals over minor infractions and the expansion of immigration enforcement into local judicial processes.

title: Executive Branch Club Opening in Georgetown
summary: A new invitation-only club called 'Executive Branch' opened in Georgetown, Washington D.C., backed by Donald Trump Jr. and megadonor Omeed Malik. According to Politico reporter Dasha Burns, membership costs over $500,000 and is designed to allow top business executives to have private conversations with Trump advisors and cabinet members. The club reportedly already has a waiting list.

title: Record-Breaking Trump Inauguration Fundraising
summary: Trump's 2025 inauguration raised an unprecedented $239 million, which combined with the $107 million from his 2017 inauguration totals $346 million—more than all other inaugural committees since 1973 combined. The single largest donor was Pilgrim's Pride at $5 million. The funds not spent on inauguration festivities can be directed toward other Trump projects with minimal oversight.

title: USDA Withdraws Biden-Era Salmonella Safety Rule
summary: The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) withdrew a Biden-era rule that would have required poultry companies to keep salmonella bacteria below certain levels. The CDC had previously stated that salmonella causes 1.35 million infections and 420 deaths annually, with the rule estimated to reduce salmonella illnesses by 25%. Pilgrim's Pride, which donated $5 million to Trump's inaugural committee, has executives on the board of the National Chicken Council that praised the withdrawal.

title: Musk's DOGE Team Working on Secret FAA 'Project Lift'
summary: Elon Musk's 'Department of Government Efficiency' (DOGE) staffers are reportedly working on a multimillion-dollar communications project at the Federal Aviation Administration called 'Project Lift.' The project appears to involve inserting Musk's Starlink into a $2.4 billion contract currently held by Verizon. FAA employees have been made to sign nondisclosure agreements, limiting public information about this taxpayer-funded project.

title: Trump Sons Seek Early Stock Sale from AI Company Advisory Roles
summary: Shortly after Trump announced the administration's push to loosen regulations for AI, his sons Donald Jr. and Eric joined the advisory board of AI company Dominari Holdings, Inc., receiving 750,000 shares each despite having no official duties. The Trumps also invested in Dominari's subsidiary, American Data Center, Inc. Dominari stock increased by over 1,000% after the Trump sons joined, and recent SEC filings show they're seeking permission to sell their shares worth $5.8 million each earlier than normally allowed.

title: Trump Administration Creating Controversial Government 'Lists' of Vulnerable Groups
summary: The Trump administration has initiated multiple data collection efforts targeting specific groups, including texting Barnard College faculty to ask if they're Jewish and creating a controversial 'disease registry' for people with autism. Additionally, the IRS has agreed to share confidential tax records with Immigration and Customs Enforcement to help deport an estimated 7 million undocumented immigrants, despite longstanding privacy protections. Critics warn these practices threaten privacy, evoke historical abuses of government data collection, and may discourage tax payments from undocumented immigrants who contributed an estimated $96.7 billion in taxes in 2022.

title: DOGE Was Bad. Schedule F Will Be Worse
summary: President Trump issued an executive order on April 18, 2025 resurrecting 'Schedule F,' which would convert approximately 50,000 federal government employees to 'at-will' status, making them effectively political appointees who serve at the president's pleasure. The order allows for the firing of civil servants for 'subversion of Presidential directives' and has been challenged by multiple lawsuits, including one from the National Treasury Employees Union arguing it violates Congressional intent. While acknowledging legitimate concerns about accountability in federal employment, the article argues this approach prioritizes personal loyalty over Constitutional obligations and would make government less effective.
